results.title: On the way to growing up: the miracle of birth
results.creator_credit: Instructional Television Services and Brigham Young University
results.brief_description: Designed to prepare the expectant parents for childbirth. Although each birth is different, each happens in a predictable sequence and learning what to expect is part of the training. Over cartoon drawings, the narrator explains the three things necessary for adequate preparation for childbirth: a positive attitude, accurate expectations and supportive techniques. The live births of three infants is recorded.

results.title: On the waves of the Adriatic
results.creator_credit: Brian McKenzie Film Productions and Brian McKenzie
results.brief_description: Melbourne filmmaker Brian McKenzie spent 5 years working on this engrossing study of a not-so-typical Brunswick household. McKenzie plays a central part as he documents the lifestyle of Graham (a youth in his 20’s), his family and friends. After having spent so long with the family, McKenzie becomes part of the furniture- a situation which enables him to dig deep into the subjects’ lives.

results.title: On the waterfront [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Sam Spiegel, Columbia and Elia Kazan
results.brief_description: Filmed on location in Hoboken, New Jersey, Kazan’s film deals with trade unionism, corruption and racketeering on New York’s docks. Marlon Brando is cast as an ex-boxer who unknowingly lures a worker, planning to testify against the waterside union, to his death. His conscience drives him to redeem himself by exposing the corruption within the union hierarchy headed by Lee J. Cobb. Karl Malden and Eva Marie Saint provide the emotional and spiritual support that drive Brando to persevere in his struggle to eradicate organised crime on the waterfront and to uphold a workers right to work. Rod Steiger appears as Brando’s brother, torn between his family loyalty and loyalty to his union boss. Screenplay by Budd Schulbert based on articles by Malcolm Johnson. Photographed by Boris Kaufman. Music by Leonard Bernstein. Edited by Gene Milford. (Academy awards: Best picture, Best actor, Best supporting actress, Best cinematography, Best art direction, Best directing, Best film editing, Best screenplay)

results.title: On the trail of the torturers
results.creator_credit: Michael Ryan and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World in action”.
As Greece prepares for its first democratic election in a decade, “World in Action” focuses on the torturers who were recruited by the former dictatorship to “discourage” opposition. This is a powerful and confronting documentary containing graphic accounts by both the torturers and the victims of torture.

results.title: On the Strzelecki Track
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Jack Absalom’s outback Australia series”.
Strezelecki was an early Polish explorer and surveyor. His name is given to one of the most desolate regions of the Outback. Jack Absalom traces the Strezelecki Track from the grand beauty of the Flinders Ranges, once the ancient coastline of the Australian continent, north to Cooper’s Creek where in ancient times thousands of Aborigines lived in a paradise surrounded by desert. Many early English explorers of the continent perished here but true bushmen achieved remarkable feats. Rated: G

results.title: On the side of the angels
results.creator_credit: Peter Kaufmann, Open Channel Productions and Claire Jaeger
results.brief_description:
This film presents the story of the people involved in the
movement for peace in Australia from 1900 to the present. Using rare archival film, the program reflects on the international events that concerned and influenced many people to organise together for peace and world stability. Features Ralph Gibson, founding member against war and fascism in the 30s, Stephen Murray-Smith, peace historian, Sam Goldbloom, Council for International Cooperation and Disarmament, Jim Cairns, Deputy Prime Minister with the Whitlam government, Jean McLean, radical Victorian Labour MP and Jo Camilleri, Convenor of People for Nuclear Disarmament.
